sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
Find the determinant of the 3x3 matrix A given below:

A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 & 9 \end{bmatrix}
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)

where a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i are the elements of the matrix A:

A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix}

For the given matrix A:

A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 7 & 8 & 9 \end{bmatrix}

We have:

a = 1, b = 2, c = 3, d = 4, e = 5, f = 6, g = 7, h = 8, and i = 9

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

det(A) = 1(5*9 - 6*8) - 2(4*9 - 6*7) + 3(4*8 - 5*7)

det(A) = 1(45 - 48) - 2(36 - 42) + 3(32 - 35)

det(A) = 1(-3) - 2(-6) + 3(-3)

det(A) = -3 + 12 - 9

det(A) = 0

So, the determinant of the given matrix A is 0.
